revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[File:Francesco Casanova Battaglia di cavalleria.jpg|thumb|300px|''Cavalry Battle'', currently in the [[Louvre]]]] '''Francesco Giuseppe Casanova''' (1 June 1727, London – 8 July 1803, near [[Mödling]]) was an Italian painter who specialised in battle scenes. His older brother was [[Giacomo Casanova]], the famous adventurer, and his younger brother was [[Giovanni Battista Casanova|Giovanni Casanova]]; also a well-known painter.
== Biography == [[File:Paysans surpris par un orage.jpg|thumb|275px|left|''The Storm'', one of four "disaster paintings"]] He was born in London, where his parents, [[Zanetta Farussi]], an actress, and [[Gaetano Casanova]], an actor and dancer, had a theatrical engagement.<ref name="W">[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Casanova,_Francis_(DNB00) "Francis Casanova"] by Lionel Henry Cust, from the ''Dictionary of National Biography, 1885–1900'', Volume 09 @ Wikisource.</ref> It was rumoured that his father was actually the Prince of Wales (who shortly after became King [[George II of Great Britain|George II]]); whether for scurrilous motives or publicity is unclear.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} They returned to Venice when he was still young and, after his father's death in 1733, he and his siblings were placed in the care of the [[Grimani family]].<ref name="W" />
His career began in the workshops of [[Giovanni Antonio Guardi]],<ref name="T">[http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/francesco-giuseppe-casanova_(Enciclopedia-Italiana)/ Brief biography] from the Enciclopedia Italiana @ [[Treccani]].</ref> a very unpleasant time for him, according to the memoirs of his brother Giacomo. Later, he moved to the studios of [[Antonio Joli]], who was a set designer for the theatres owned by the Grimanis. This was also, apparently, unsatisfactory and he took up studies with the battle painter, [[Francesco Simonini]].<ref name="T" /> In 1751, upon his brother Giovanni's advice, he went to Paris and became an apprentice of [[Charles Parrocel]].<ref name="W" /> The following year, after Parrocel's death, he went to Dresden and spent a year studying the battle paintings at the "Gallery of the Electors of Saxony". In 1758, he returned to Paris and set himself up as a free-lance artist.
Success did not come immediately, and his first exhibition was a failure. In 1761, he became a [[wikt:supernumerary|supernumerary]] member of the [[Académie royale de peinture et de sculpture]] and was promoted to full member in 1763.<ref name="T" /> As a result of favourable criticism from [[Denis Diderot]], he began to receive commissions from the aristocracy.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4nQGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA149&lpg=PA149&dq=Diderot,+Oeuvres+compl%C3%A8tes.J.+Ass%C3%A9zat&source=bl&ots=MR5tTrs8KC&sig=K-hIlRxaem9g659UAp0FYaQkrSc&hl=it&ei=Ae1uS_jYK5_kmgO5l7jUBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=&f=false Diderot on Francesco Casanova, ''Salon'' 1761, in Diderot, ''Beaux-Arts, Essais sur la peinture'', Garnier frères 1879 pp. 149–150] @ Google Books.</ref> Diderot would later express negative opinions about Casanova's work, but his reputation was already made.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=4nQGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA219&lpg=PA219Beaux-Arts,%20Essais%20sur%20la%20peinture,%20par%20J.%20Ass%E9zat,%20I,%20Paris,%20Garnier%20fr%E8res%201879%20pp.%20149-150&dq=Diderot,+Salon+1763+J.+Ass%E9zat&source=bl&ots=MR5tTru9IC&sig=LNRWKC9GrZ1u5VhFMb7O3Rv3d8s&hl=it&ei=PvVuS9rdEdOrsAb46MiABg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAcQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=&f=false Diderot on Francesco Casanova, ''Salon'' 1763 in Diderot, ''Beaux-Arts, Essais sur la peinture'', Garnier frères 1879 p. 219] @ Google Books.</ref> His fame soon spread eastward and he received commissions from [[Catherine the Great]] for the [[Hermitage Museum|Hermitage]], beginning in 1768. Two years later, he produced his four famous "disaster paintings", which were purchased by [[Jean-Benjamin de la Borde]] on behalf of King [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]]. In 1771, he exhibited two large canvases depicting scenes from the [[Thirty Years' War]] (The [[Battle of Freiburg]] and the [[Battle of Lens]]) and once again won Diderot's approval.
===Personal life=== [[File:Casanova Cattle on pasture.jpg|thumb|300px|''Cattle on pasture'', [[Łazienki Palace|Palace on the Water]] in [[Warsaw]].]] In 1762, he had married Jeanne-Marie Jolivet (1734–1773) a ballerina with the theatre of the [[Comédie-Italienne]] who was known as "Mademoiselle d'Alancour". Her professional connections also supplied him with many clients. In 1775, two years after her death, he married the recently widowed Jeanne Cathérine Delachaux (1748–1818). The marriage turned out to be a disaster, so he abandoned her in 1783,<ref>[http://www.histoireeurope.fr/RechercheLocution.php?Locutions=Jeanne+Catherine+Delachaux Jeanne Delachaux] @ Histoire de l'Europe.</ref> aided and abetted by Giacomo. He took refuge in Vienna, under the protection of Prince [[Charles-Joseph, 7th Prince of Ligne|Charles Joseph de Ligne]], who introduced him to [[Wenzel Anton, Prince of Kaunitz-Rietberg|Chancellor Kaunitz]]. It appears that Francesco was almost as extroverted and entertaining as his brother Giacomo, so he quickly became popular at the Viennese Court.
In addition to his paintings, he produced designs for [[tapestries]] and upholstery which proved very lucrative. From 1770 to 1787, the [[Beauvais tapestry|Royal Beauvais Manufactory]] used more than seventy of his patterns.
Despite his success and his many aristocratic clients, he squandered his money, was perpetually in debt, and died in poverty at his home near Mödling. The year is generally given as 1803, although some sources have 1805 or 1807.
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Roland Kanz, ''Die Brüder Casanova. Künstler u. Abenteurer'', Deutscher Kunstverlag, 2013 {{ISBN|978-3-422-07211-4}} *Ernest Dumonthier, ''Les Tapisseries d'Ameublement de la Manufacture Royale de Beauvais d'après François Casanova'', Albert Morancé, 1921.
==External links== {{commons category|Francesco Casanova}} *[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_2=AUTR&VALUE_2=CASANOVA%20FRANCESCO%20GIUSEPPE More works by Casanova] @ the [[Joconde|Base Joconde]] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=4nQGAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA326&lpg=PA326Beaux-Arts,%20Essais%20sur%20la%20peinture,%20par%20J.%20Ass%E9zat,%20I,%20Paris,%20Garnier%20fr%E8res%201879%20pp.%20149-150&dq=Diderot,+Salon+1763+J.+Ass%E9zat&source=bl&ots=MR5tTru9IC&sig=LNRWKC9GrZ1u5VhFMb7O3Rv3d8s&hl=it&ei=PvVuS9rdEdOrsAb46MiABg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAcQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=&f=false Another critique by Diderot from the Salon of 1765] @ Google Books.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Casanova, Francesco Giuseppe}} [[Category:1727 births]] [[Category:1803 deaths]] [[Category:People from London]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to France]] [[Category:18th-century Italian painters]] [[Category:Italian male painters]] [[Category:Italian engravers]] [[Category:Venetian painters]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to Austria]] [[Category:Military art]] [[Category:Tapestry artists]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Globe Theatre, Boston (1903)}}
[[Image:1873 ChesneyWold GlobeTheatre Boston USA March24.png|thumb|150px|right|Programme for performance of H.A. Rendle's "Chesney Wold," 1873]] [[Image:1886 Globe Theatre Boston map byBromley BPL 12259 detail 2.png|thumb|right|Detail of 1886 map of Boston, showing Globe Theatre]] [[Image:GlobeTheatre WashingtonSt StrangersGuideToBoston 1883.png|thumb|150px|right|Seating chart, 1883]]
The '''Globe Theatre''' (est.1871) was a [[Theater (structure)|playhouse]] in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], in the 19th century. It was located at 598 [[Washington Street (Boston)|Washington Street]],<ref name="neal1">{{cite news |newspaper=The Bay State Banner |last1=Neal |first1=Anthony W. |date=February 4, 2016 |title=Sergeant Horatio J. Homer: Boston’s first black police officer |page=1 |url=http://baystatebanner.com/news/2016/feb/04/sergeant-horatio-j-homer-bostons-first-black-polic/ |accessdate=November 4, 2017}}</ref> near the corner of Essex Street.<ref>The Globe occupied the site on Washington Street opposite the [[Park Theatre (Boston)|Park Theatre]], on the block between Essex Street and Hayward Place: no.364 Washington Street, 1871-ca.1876 (Boston Almanac. 1871, 1875) later re-numbered as no.598 Washington Street, ca.1877-ca.1894 (Boston Almanac. 1877, 1881, 1887, 1891, 1894)</ref> Arthur Cheney oversaw the Globe until 1876.<ref>Boston Daily Globe, July 17, 1872; Boston Evening Transcript, Sept. 9, 1876</ref><ref name="bacon1892" /> From 1871-1873 it occupied the former theatre of [[Selwyn's Theatre|John H. Selwyn]].<ref name="bacon1892">{{Citation |publisher = Post Pub. Co. |publication-place = Boston |title = Boston of to-day: a glance at its history and characteristics. With biographical sketches and portraits of many of its professional and business men |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL7162628M/Boston_of_to-day |author = Richard Herndon and Edwin Bacon, eds. |publication-date = 1892 |oclc = 4430662 }}</ref> After a fire in May 1873, the Globe re-opened on the same site in December 1874.<ref>"Chronicle of events." Boston Almanac. 1875</ref> Architect B.F. Dwight designed the new building.<ref>Benjamin Franklin Dwight (d.1893). American Architect and Building News, Oct. 14, 1893</ref> From 1877-1893 John Stetson served as proprietor;<ref>Boston Daily Globe, May 26, 1878; 22 Sept., 1880; Boston Evening Transcript, March 2, 1883; Dec. 3, 1887. Boston Globe, January 22, 1893</ref><ref>John Stetson (d.1896). New York Times, April 19, 1896</ref> some regarded him as "a theatrical producer with a reputation for illiteracy in his day such as [[Samuel Goldwyn]] has achieved" in the 1960s.<ref name="Doris M. Alexander 1960">Doris M. Alexander. "Oedipus in Victorian New York." American Quarterly, Vol. 12, No. 3 (Autumn, 1960)</ref> The theatre burned down in January 1894.<ref>Boston Daily Globe, January 3, 1894</ref>
[[Horatio J. Homer]], Boston's first African-American police officer, worked as a janitor at the Globe Theatre before being hired by the [[Boston Police Department]].<ref name="neal1" />
==Performances==
===1870s=== * H.A. Rendle's Chesney Wold, with [[Fanny Janauschek|Madame Janauschek]]<ref>Boston Daily Globe, March 7, 1873</ref> * [[George L. Fox (clown)|Fox]]'s Humpty Dumpty<ref>Boston Daily Globe, July 17, 1873</ref> * [[Augustin Daly]]'s Pique, with Miss Jeffries-Lewis<ref name="ReferenceA">Boston Evening Transcript, Sept. 9, 1876</ref> * [[Edward Askew Sothern|E.A. Sothern]] as [[Lord Dundreary]]<ref name="ReferenceA"/> * "[[The Sea of Ice (play)|Sea of Ice]]" with Miss Maud Granger as Ocarita and [[George C. Boniface|Mr. George Boniface]] as Carlos, Monday, January 28, 1878 <ref>Globe Theatre Programme</ref> * Eliza Weathersby's Froliques<ref>Boston Daily Globe, May 26, 1878</ref> * Miss [[Kate Claxton]] in ''[[The Two Orphans (play)|Two Orphans]]''
===1880s=== * "Rice's new extravaganza combination in the opera comique Calino"<ref>Boston Daily Globe, 22 Sept., 1880</ref> * Othello, starring [[Tommaso Salvini|Salvini]]<ref name="ReferenceB">Boston Daily Globe, January 9, 1881</ref> * L.R. Shewell's Debt of Honor<ref name="ReferenceB"/> * [[Oscar Wilde]] lecture June 2, 1882<ref>[http://www.oscarwildeinamerica.org/lectures-1882/june/0602-boston.html Oscar Wilde In America]</ref> * [[Oedipus Rex|Oedipus]]<ref name="Doris M. Alexander 1960"/> * 14 Days, with [[Charles Wyndham (actor)|Charles Wyndham]]<ref>Boston Evening Transcript, March 2, 1883</ref> * We, Us & Co., with Mestayer-Vaughn<ref>Boston Daily Globe, May 17, 1885</ref> * Gilbert & Sullivan's [[The Mikado|Mikado]], with Helen Lamont and [[Signor Brocolini]]<ref>Boston Daily Globe, May 22, 1887</ref> * As in a Looking-Glass, with [[Lillie Langtry|Mrs. Langtry]]<ref name="Boston Daily Globe, Dec. 3, 1887">Boston Daily Globe, Dec. 3, 1887</ref> * [[Hanlon-Lees|The Hanlons]] in "Fantasma"<ref name="Boston Daily Globe, Dec. 3, 1887"/> * Princess Ida<ref>{{Citation |publisher = State Pub. Co. |publication-place = Boston |title = The playgoers' year-book, for 1888 |url = http://openlibrary.org/books/OL17937497M/The_playgoers'_year-book_for_1888. |author = Charles E. L. Wingate |publication-date = 1888 }}</ref> * Ibsen's [[A Doll's House]], with [[Beatrice Cameron]]<ref>[[Donald Pizer]]. "The Radical Drama in Boston 1889-1891." New England Quarterly, Vol. 31, No. 3 (Sep., 1958)</ref> * ''[[The Oolah]]'' (1889)<ref name="bostontwo">(21 December 1889). [http://idnc.library.illinois.edu/cgi-bin/illinois?a=d&d=NYC18891221.2.45# Massachusetts], ''[[New York Clipper]]'' (it played a month in Boston)</ref>
===1890s=== * ''The Lion Tamer'', with [[Francis Wilson (actor)|Francis Wilson]]<ref>Boston Globe, January 22, 1893</ref> * Ali Baba, with American Extravaganza Co.<ref>Boston Globe, March 5, 1893</ref> * The Crust of Society<ref>Boston Globe, April 4, 1893</ref> * Prince Karl, with Richard Mansfield<ref>Boston Globe, Sept. 21 1893</ref> * [[Hanlon-Lees|Hanlon Brothers]]' "mechanical fairy spectacle Superba"<ref>Boston Daily Globe, December 29, 1893</ref> * La Cigale, with [[Lillian Russell]] <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=YvbGHAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Globe+Theatre+%28Boston,+Mass.%29%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=n4LRUfCPE-ni4AOS9oG4BA&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBTge Lillian Russell Opera Comique Co. in La Cigale: An Original Opera Comique]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category|Globe Theatre (Boston, Massachusetts)}} * NYPL. [http://digitalgallery.nypl.org/nypldigital/id?TH-16312 Globe Theatre Company], Boston (fl. 1870) * [http://www.bostonathenaeum.org/node/224 Boston Athenæum Theater History], Globe Theatre, Boston
{{Boston theatres}} {{coord|42|21|10.61|N|71|3|45.19|W|type:landmark_region:US-MA|display=title}}
[[Category:Cultural history of Boston]] [[Category:19th century in Boston]] [[Category:Boston Theater District]] [[Category:1871 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Former theatres in Boston]] [[Category:Event venues established in 1871]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1874]] [[Category:Burned buildings and structures in the United States]]

revision.text:
A '''harpsichordist''' is a person who plays the [[harpsichord]].
Many [[baroque music|baroque]] composers played the harpsichord, including [[Johann Sebastian Bach]], [[Domenico Scarlatti]], [[George Frideric Handel]], [[François Couperin]] and [[Jean-Philippe Rameau]]. At this time, it was common for such musicians also to play the [[pipe organ|organ]], and all [[keyboard instrument]]s, and to direct orchestral music while playing [[Figured bass|continuo]] on the instrument.
Modern harpsichord playing can be roughly divided into three eras, beginning with the career of the influential reviver of the instrument, [[Wanda Landowska]]. At this stage of the 'harpsichord revival', players generally used harpsichords of a heavy, piano-influenced type made by makers such as [[Ignaz Pleyel|Pleyel]]; the revival of the instrument also led some composers to write specifically for the instrument, often on the request of Landowska. An influential later group of English players using post-Pleyel instruments by Thomas Goff and the [[Robert Goble|Goble]] family included [[George Malcolm (musician)|George Malcolm]] and [[Thurston Dart]]. Beginning in the 1920s, [[Gavin Williamson (harpsichordist)|Gavin Williamson]] and [[Philip Manuel]] also helped popularize the harpsichord through concert tours, and were, in fact, the world's only full-time harpsichord duo, known as Manuel and Williamson, performing throughout North American and Europe. They had studied for many years with Wanda Landowska both in France and in New York. In the 1930s Manual and Williamson made the first recordings of the Bach multiple keyboard concerti with members of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and the duo also gave the American premiere performance of Bach's Concerto in C major for two harpsichords. In addition, they gave American premieres of many works of Couperin and Rameau, among other composers. <ref>{{citation |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1989-04-25/news/8904070185_1_harpsichords-music-mr-williamson|title=Gavin Williamson: Helped save harpsichord|publisher=Chicago Trubune|accessdate=11 July 2014}}</ref>
The next generation of harpsichordists were pioneers of modern performance on instruments built according to the [[Authentic performance|authentic practices]] of the earlier period, following the research of such scholar-builders as [[Frank Hubbard]] and [[William Dowd]]. This generation of performers included such players as [[Isolde Ahlgrimm|Isohlde Ahlgrimm]], [[Ralph Kirkpatrick]], [[Igor Kipnis]], and [[Gustav Leonhardt]]. More recently, many outstanding harpsichordists have appeared, such as [[Scott Ross (harpsichordist)|Scott Ross]], [[Trevor Pinnock]], [[Kenneth Gilbert]], [[Christopher Hogwood]], [[Jos van Immerseel]], [[Ton Koopman]], [[Gary Cooper (musician)|Gary Cooper]] and [[David Schrader]], with many of them also directing a [[baroque orchestra]] from the instrument.
==References== {{Reflist}}
*Palmer, Larry (1989) ''Harpsichord in America: A Twentieth Century Revival'', Indiana University Press, {{ISBN|978-0-253-32710-9}}. Contains detailed information on several American harpsichordists.
==See also== *[[List of harpsichordists]]
[[Category:Harpsichord| ]] [[Category:Harpsichordists| ]] [[Category:Occupations in music]]
{{musical-instrument-stub}}

page.title: Horton and the Kwuggerbug and More Lost Stories

revision.comment: Edited infobox: page number, ISBN, OCLC number, LC classification
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | | name = Horton and the Kwuggerbug and More Lost Stories | title_orig = | translator = | image = Horton and the Kwuggerbug cover 2014.jpg | caption = | author = [[Dr. Seuss]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = | publisher = ''[[Redbook]]'' (magazines)
[[Random House]] (book) | pub_date = 1950 ("Marco Comes Late" and "How Officer Pat Saved the Whole Town")
1951 ("Horton and the Kwuggerbug")
1955 ("The Hoobub and the Grinch")
2014 | media_type = Print | pages = 53 | isbn = 978-0375973420 | isbn_note = ''(first edition, hardcover)'' | oclc = 866615089 | congress = PZ8.3.S477 Hoq 2014 | preceded_by = [[The Bippolo Seed and Other Lost Stories]] | followed_by = [[What Pet Should I Get?]] }} '''''Horton and the Kwuggerbug and More Lost Stories''''' is an anthology of children's stories written and illustrated by [[Dr. Seuss]], published posthumously by [[Random House]] in 2014. ==Background== The four stories in this book were originally published as installments of a monthly column that Dr. Seuss wrote for ''[[Redbook]]'' during the 1950s.{{cite news|last1=Migaki|first1=Lauren|title=Horton Meets A... Who?|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/09/08/345880696/horton-meets-a-who-introducing-the-kwuggerbug-from-seuss-lost-stories|accessdate=12 March 2015|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=8 September 2014}} Dr. Seuss died in 1991, but the stories were later rediscovered by Seuss scholar Charles D. Cohen.{{cite news|last1=Taube|first1=Michael|title=BOOK REVIEW: ‘Horton and the Kwuggerbug and More Lost Stories’|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/oct/6/book-review-the-lost-and-found-dr-seuss/?page=all|accessdate=12 March 2015|work=[[The Washington Times]]|date=6 October 2014}} ==Plots== The four stories included in the book are as follows: *"Horton and the Kwuggerbug": A Kwuggerbug lands on [[Horton the Elephant]]'s trunk and asks him to take him to his beezlenut tree, which Horton agrees to since when they get there the bug promises Horton will get half the nuts. The journey to the beezlenut tree is quite hazardous, and Horton goes through all the hardships including swimming across a large crocodile infested river and climbing a large and rocky mountain, with the Kwuggerbug taking advantage of Horton's good nature. In the end, the Kwuggerbug tries to double-cross Horton, but a well-timed sneeze makes things more even. *"Marco Comes Late": Marco from ''[[And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street]]'' explains to his teacher why he was late for school. His explanation involves a bird who landed on his books and laid an egg there, and various animals who argue over whether he should protect the egg or get to school on time. In the end, the teacher sees through the tall tale for the morsel of truth. *"How Officer Pat Saved the Whole Town": Officer Pat sees a gnat about to disturb a cat and realizes this could be the start of a string of disasters that could obliterate the town. He intervenes and the town is saved. *"The Hoobub and the Grinch": A very short story in which a [[Grinch]] convinces a Hoobub that a piece of green string is better than the sun. ==Reception== Michael Taube of ''[[The Washington Times]]'' was enthusiastic about the book, writing, "If you loved Dr. Seuss as a child (and as an adult), these little-known stories will bring back many fond memories." The reviewer for ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' was more critical, stating, "By no means gems, these archives suggest how Geisel tinkered with characters, developed his signature [[tetrameter]], and commented on ethical issues, circa 1950."{{cite news|title=Horton and the Kwuggerbug: And More Lost Stories|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-385-38298-4|accessdate=12 March 2015|work=[[Publishers Weekly]]}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Dr. Seuss}} [[Category:2014 short story collections]] [[Category:2014 children's books]] [[Category:Books by Dr. Seuss]] [[Category:American picture books]] [[Category:Literature featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]] [[Category:Animal tales]]

{{More footnotes|date=October 2017}}
[[File:Great Wave off Kanagawa2.jpg|thumb|260px|[[The Great Wave off Kanagawa]], [[Katsushika Hokusai]]]] [[File:Hiroshige, Sudden shower over Shin-Ōhashi bridge and Atake, 1857.jpg|thumb|200px|''[[Sudden Shower over Shin-Ōhashi bridge and Atake|Sudden Shower at the Atake Bridge]]'', [[Hiroshige]], 1856]]
'''Japanese art''' covers a wide range of art styles and media, including [[Jōmon Pottery|ancient pottery]], [[Japanese sculpture|sculpture]], [[Ink wash painting|ink painting]] and [[Japanese calligraphy|calligraphy]] on silk and paper, ''[[ukiyo-e]]'' paintings and [[woodblock printing|woodblock prints]], ceramics, [[origami]], and more recently [[manga]]—modern Japanese [[cartoon]]ing and comics—along with a myriad of other types. It has a long history, ranging from the beginnings of human habitation in Japan, sometime in the 10th millennium BC, to the present.
Japan has been subject to sudden invasions of new ideas followed by long periods of minimal contact with the outside world. Over time the Japanese developed the ability to absorb, imitate, and finally assimilate those elements of foreign culture that complemented their aesthetic preferences. The earliest complex art in Japan was produced in the 7th and 8th centuries in connection with [[Buddhism]]. In the 9th century, as the Japanese began to turn away from China and develop indigenous forms of expression, the secular arts became increasingly important; until the late 15th century, both religious and secular arts flourished. After the [[Ōnin War]] (1467–1477), Japan entered a period of political, social, and economic disruption that lasted for over a century. In the state that emerged under the leadership of the [[Tokugawa shogunate]], organized religion played a much less important role in people's lives, and the arts that survived were primarily secular.
[[Painting]] is the preferred artistic expression in Japan, practiced by amateurs and professionals alike. Until modern times, the Japanese wrote with a [[Ink brush|brush]] rather than a [[pen]], and their familiarity with brush techniques has made them particularly sensitive to the values and [[aesthetics]] of painting. With the rise of popular culture in the [[Edo period]], a style of woodblock prints became a major form and its techniques were fine tuned to produce colorful prints. The Japanese, in this period, found [[sculpture]] a much less sympathetic medium for artistic expression; most Japanese sculpture is associated with [[religion]], and the medium's use declined with the lessening importance of traditional Buddhism.
[[Japanese pottery|Japanese ceramics]] are among the finest in the world and include the earliest known artifacts of their culture. In [[Japanese architecture|architecture]], Japanese preferences for natural materials and an interaction of interior and exterior space are clearly expressed.
== History of Japanese art ==
=== Jōmon art === The first settlers of Japan, the [[Jōmon]] people (c. 11000 – c. 300 BC), named for the [[rope|cord]] markings that decorated the surfaces of their clay vessels, were nomadic hunter-gatherers who later practiced organized farming and built cities with populations of hundreds if not thousands. They built simple houses of wood and thatch set into shallow earthen pits to provide warmth from the soil. They crafted [[Jōmon pottery|lavishly decorated pottery storage vessels]], clay figurines called ''[[dogū]]'', and crystal jewels.
