{{Infobox award | name = Spectrum Grand Master Award | image = | imagesize = | caption = | description = The best in contemporary fantasy, science fiction, and horror artwork. | presenter = Spectrum Fantastic Art | year = 1995 | website = [http://spectrumfantasticart.com/ Spectrum Fantastic Art] }} The [[Spectrum Award]] for Grand Master has been awarded annually since 1995 by the Spectrum Fantastic Art Advisory Board.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.spectrumfantasticart.com/board.php|title = Spectrum Fantastic Advisory Board|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
A Grand Master, as Arnie Fenner (SFA Advisory Board member) has explained, is an artist who has worked for at least twenty years at a consistently high level of quality; who has influenced and inspired other artists; and who has left his or her mark on the field as a whole. "Craft alone" he writes, " is not sufficient to receive the honor: There are many painters who produce solid professional work. But (and this is the key) it fails to resonate. It is admired in the moment and immediately forgotten. A Grand Master's art, on the other hand, gets stuck in the viewer's heart and memory.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Spectrum 21: The Best In Contemporary Fantastic Art|last = Fleskes|first = John|publisher = Flesk Publications|year = 2014|isbn = 978-1-933865-58-4|location = |pages = 15}}</ref>
Arnie Fenner also states "At the time of the designation is given the artist must be living. Recently, two GM honorees died prior to the announcement --Al Williamson and Ralph McQuarrie-- which confused a few people, but...both were still with us when the Board bestowed the honor."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://muddycolors.blogspot.com/2012/10/grand-master.html|title = Grand Master post by Arnie Fenner on Muddy Colors|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

page.title: The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Frans Hals 013.jpg|thumb|''The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627'']] '''''The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627''''' refers to a [[schutterstuk]] painted by [[Frans Hals]] for the St. George (or St. Joris) civic guard of [[Haarlem]], and today is considered one of the main attractions of the [[Frans Hals Museum]] there.
In this group, each man wears a sash belonging to the color of the "rot", in this painting all three are represented with their flag-bearers wearing the colours Orange, white or blue. These officers were selected by the council of Haarlem to serve for three years, and this group had just finished their tenure and celebrated their end of service with a portrait. The man with the orange sash holding a glass of wine sitting at the table on the left and looking at Captain [[Michiel de Wael]] with an empty glass, is Colonel [[Aart Jansz Druyvesteyn]], who heads the table.
The men featured are from left to right Lieutenant [[Cornelis Boudewijns]] (standing above Colonel Aernout Druyvesteyn), Captain [[Nicolaes Verbeek]], Flag bearer [[Boudewijn van Offenberg]], Lieutenant [[Jacob Pietersz Olycan]], Captain Michiel de Wael, and above him, standing, is Flag bearer [[Dirck Dicx]] looking down at Jacob Olycan. Just behind him in the background is the servant [[Arent Jacobsz Koets]], and below him, seated, is Lieutenant [[Frederik Coning]]. Behind the servant in the far right, is the flag bearer [[Jacob Cornelisz Schout]] who towers above the dwarf in the lower right, Captain [[Nicolaes le Febure]].
==St. Jorisdoelen== [[File:Grote Houtstraat 142 Haarlem RM 19243.jpg|thumb|View of one of the halls of the St. Jorisdoelen]] The painting previously hung with others in the old "St. Jorisdoelen" complex, known today as the [[Proveniershuis]].<ref>[http://monumentenregister.cultureelerfgoed.nl/php/main.php?cAction=search&cOffset=1&cLimit=25&oOrder=ASC&cSubmit=1&sCompMonNr=19243 report] on [[Rijksmonument]] number 19243</ref> The paintings by Hals and others hung in the main hall of the complex in the [[Grote Houtstraat]]. Today a [[hofje]] with the main hall used as a restaurant, the main buildings were used for years as an inn, where the schutterstukken were tourist attractions. Today all of the schutterstukken that once hung here have been transferred to the Frans Hals Museum.
==See also== * ''[[The Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1616]]'' * ''[[The Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1639]]'' *[[List of paintings by Frans Hals]]
==References== {{reflist}} *De Haarlemse Schuttersstukken, by Jhr. Mr. C.C. van Valkenburg, pp. 47-76, Haerlem : jaarboek 1961, {{ISSN|0927-0728}} *Frans Hals: Exhibition on the Occasion of the Centenary of the Municipal Museum at Haarlem, 1862-1962., pp 36-38, publication Frans Hals Museum, 1962
{{Frans Hals}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Banquet of the Officers of the St George Militia Company in 1627}} [[Category:Paintings by Frans Hals]] [[Category:History of Haarlem]] [[Category:Militia group portraits]] [[Category:Collections in the Frans Hals Museum]] [[Category:Flags in art]] [[Category:Food and drink paintings]]

{{Infobox Painting | image_file = Actaeon.jpg | painting_alignment = right | image_size = 370px | title = The Death of Actaeon | artist = [[Titian]] | year = {{circa|1559–1575}} | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 178.4 | width_metric = 198.1 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | city = [[London]] | museum = [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] }} '''''The Death of Actaeon''''' is a late work by the Italian Renaissance painter [[Titian]], painted in oil on canvas from about 1559 to his death in 1576 and now in the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] in London. It is very probably one of the two paintings the artist stated he had started and hopes to finish (one of which he calls "[[Actaeon]] mauled by [[Actaeon#Names_of_the_dogs_who_devoured_Actaeon|hounds]]") in a letter to their commissioner [[Philip II of Spain]] during June 1559. However, most of Titian's work on this painting possibly dates to the late 1560s, but with touches from the 1570s. Titian seems never to have resolved it to his satisfaction, and the painting apparently remained in his studio until his death in 1576.<ref>Penny, 250, 253</ref> There has been considerable debate as to whether it is finished or not, as with other very late Titians, such as the ''[[Flaying of Marsyas (Titian)|Flaying of Marsyas]]'', which unlike this has a signature, perhaps an indication of completion.<ref>Penny, 248-252; Jaffé, 27-28, 59, 151-153, 166, the various authors offering a variety of views.</ref> [[File:Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels - Petworth House.jpg|thumb|This painting is visible upper-right in ''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels (Petworth)]]'', 1651]]
It is a sequel of Titian's work ''[[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|Diana and Actaeon]]'' showing the story's tragic conclusion, which approximately follows the Roman poet [[Ovid]]'s account in the ''[[Metamorphoses]]'': after Actaeon surprised the goddess [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]] bathing naked in the woods, she transformed him into a stag and he was attacked and killed by his own hounds.<ref name=nationalgallery-death>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/titian-the-death-of-actaeon "The Death of Actaeon"]. ''[[National Gallery]]''. London.</ref>
Both paintings belong to a group of large-scale mythological paintings inspired by the ''Metamorphoses'' and referred to by Titian himself as ‘poesie’, the visual equivalent of poetry, which he began producing for Philip II of Spain in 1551<ref>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/learn-about-art/titians-poesie-paintings "Titian’s ‘poesie’ paintings"]. ''National Gallery''. London.</ref> and which also include ''[[Danaë (Titian series)|Danaë]]'' (many versions, Philip's in the [[Prado]], [[Madrid]]), ''[[Venus and Adonis (Titian)|Venus and Adonis]]'' (private collection, London, but also other versions), ''[[Perseus and Andromeda (Titian)|Perseus and Andromeda]]'' ([[Wallace Collection]], London), ''[[The Rape of Europa (Titian)|The Rape of Europa]]'' ([[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum]], [[Boston]]), ''[[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|Diana and Actaeon]]'' and ''[[Diana and Callisto]]'' (shared by [[National Gallery of Scotland]] with NG London).<ref>[http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/learn-about-art/titians-poesie-paintings/*/viewPage/3 "Titian's 'poesie' in Britain"]. ''National Gallery''. London.</ref> However, as ''The Death of Actaeon'' was never delivered to Philip, it is not always counted in the series.
==Subject== Ovid's account does not include Diana herself pursuing Actaeon, or shooting at him, though in some other classical accounts she does chase him. She seems to have just loosed an arrow, but there is no sign of the arrow in the painting, nor is the bowstring visible. The goddess does not have her attribute of the small crescent in her hair that Titian's other two depictions in the ''poesie'' do, which troubled one early critic.<ref>Penny, 252-257; Jaffé, 166</ref>
There were ancient reliefs and [[engraved gem]]s showing either Diana hunting with dogs, or Actaeon being attacked by his dogs, and a few Renaissance works, but the subject was rare, and "it may be that Titian had never seen another painting or other representation of the subject."<ref>Penny, 252-253, 252 quoted; Jaffé, 122</ref>
==History== It was probably still in Titian's studio at his death in 1576, and presumably sold in Venice by his heirs. It probably belonged to the famous Venetian collection of [[Bartolomeo della Nave]], most of which was bought for [[James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton]] (then still a Marquess) in 1636-38, one of the great collectors of the period in Britain. Hamilton's brother-in-law, [[Basil Feilding, 2nd Earl of Denbigh]] (as he later became) was English ambassador to Venice, and helped to arrange the purchase. A list of available paintings he sent Hamilton includes "A Diana shooting Adonis in forme of a Hart not quite finished" by Titian.<ref>Penny, 253</ref>
Hamilton, who was a Royalist commander in the [[English Civil War]], was captured and executed in 1649 after losing the [[Battle of Preston (1648)|Battle of Preston]] to [[Oliver Cromwell]]. This, like most of his collection, was bought by [[Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria]], Governor of the Spanish Netherlands from 1647 to 1656. The painting appears (looking rather lighter in tone than today) in [[David Teniers the Younger]]'s painting of the ''[[Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm (Brussels)|Gallery of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm]]'' (1651, now [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]], Brussels),<ref>Penny, 253; [https://www.fine-arts-museum.be/nl/de-collectie/david-ii-teniers-aartshertog-leopold-willem-in-zijn-galerij-italiaanse-schilderijen Aartshertog Leopold Willem in zijn galerij Italiaanse schilderijen] in the [[Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium]] collection</ref> as well as his different versions of the subject now in [[Petworth House]] and the [[Kunsthistorisches Museum]] in Vienna.
The archduke seems to have given it to Queen [[Christina of Sweden]], whose route into exile went through the [[Spanish Netherlands]], before she settled in Rome. It does not appear in an inventory of her collection made in [[Antwerp]] in 1656, but is in one made in Rome in 1662 or 1663.<ref>Penny, 253-254</ref> After her death it eventually passed, with much of her collection, into the [[Orleans Collection]] in Paris in 1721. Like most of the collection, it was bought by a consortium in London after the [[French Revolution]], and then sold in 1798 to [[Sir Abraham Hume, 2nd Baronet]] for the modest sum of 200 guineas, the price no doubt reflecting that it was considered by Hume and others as unfinished.<ref>Penny, 255-257; Jaffé, 166</ref> Hume described it as "a great painting never finished but quite beautiful".<ref>Penny, 252, translating from the Italian.</ref>
Hume was the author of the first [[monograph]] on Titian, published in 1829, and "was especially appreciative of preliminary sketches by Venetian artists (or what he believed to be such)."<ref>Penny, 204, 254 (quoted)</ref> His collection passed by descent to [[Adelbert Brownlow-Cust, 3rd Earl Brownlow]], who was made a Trustee of the National Gallery in 1897. By 1914 Brownlow needed to raise some cash, and offered the gallery this painting for £5,000 and a portrait by [[Anthony van Dyck]] for £10,000, writing "I only ask from the Gallery what I consider to be a very low price because I am anxious to see them in the gallery".<ref>Penny, 255</ref>
The van Dyck was bought but the Titian declined, because of the opposition of another trustee, [[Alfred de Rothschild]], who declared that the Titian "would not fetch £5 at [[Christie's]]". Other trustees may have been in favour but the "difficult character" of Rothschild, who was hoped to be planning a bequest to the gallery, might have resigned if the purchase was made. In 1919 the painting was bought via the dealers [[Colnaghi's]] for £60,000 by [[Henry Lascelles, 6th Earl of Harewood]] (then Viscount Lascelles), giving "the measure of Rothschild's expertise and of Brownlow's generosity".<ref>Penny, 255</ref>
In 1971, when the painting had already been on loan to the National Gallery for ten years, the trustees of the [[George Lascelles, 7th Earl of Harewood|7th Earl]] sold the painting at [[Christie's]] for £1,680,000. It was bought by the dealer Julius Weitzner and swiftly resold to the [[J. Paul Getty Museum]] in [[Malibu, California|Malibu]] for £1,763,000. At this point an export licence was needed, and the [[Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art]] suspended granting one for one year to allow a British buyer to match this price.<ref>Penny, 255</ref> The public campaign in 1971 to buy it for the United Kingdom was one of the great successes of [[Martin Davies (museum director)|Martin Davies]]'s directorship of the [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]], despite Davies's own lukewarm enthusiasm for the painting. It was eventually purchased in 1972 (as catalogue number NG6420) with £1,000,000 from the gallery's funds and a special Treasury grant matching other donations pound for pound; these included £100,000 from the [[The Art Fund|Art Fund]] and £50,000 from the [[Pilgrim Trust]], the rest raised by a public appeal, then a great innovation.<ref>Penny, 255</ref>
==''Poesie'' mythological series== * ''[[Danaë (Titian series)|Danaë]]'', delivered to Philip in 1553, now Wellington Collection, with earlier and later versions. * [[Venus and Adonis (Titian)|''Venus and Adonis'']], Museo del Prado, delivered 1554, and several other versions * ''[[Perseus and Andromeda (Titian)|Perseus and Andromeda]]'', [[Wallace Collection]], c. 1554–56 * [[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|''Diana and Actaeon'']], 1556–59, owned jointly by London's [[National Gallery]] and the [[National Gallery of Scotland]] in Edinburgh * ''[[Diana and Callisto]]'', 1556–59, owned jointly by London's [[National Gallery]] and the [[National Gallery of Scotland]] in Edinburgh * ''[[The Rape of Europa (Titian)|The Rape of Europa]]'', c. 1560–62, [[Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum]] * ''The Death of Actaeon'', [[National Gallery]], never delivered, and often not counted in the series, c. 1559 onwards {{-}}
<gallery> File:Tizian - Danae receiving the Golden Rain - Prado.jpg|''[[Danaë (Titian series)|Danaë]]'' File:Venus and Adonis by Titian.jpg|''[[Venus and Adonis (Titian)|Venus and Adonis]]'' File:Perseo y Andrómeda, por Tiziano.jpg|''[[Perseus and Andromeda (Titian)|Perseus and Andromeda]]'' File:Titian - Diana and Actaeon - Google Art Project.jpg|[[Diana and Actaeon (Titian)|''Diana and Actaeon'']] File:TitianDianaCallistoEdinburgh.jpg|''[[Diana and Callisto]]'' File:Tizian 085.jpg|[[The Rape of Europa (Titian)|''The Rape of Europa'']] File:Titian - The Death of Actaeon - Google Art Project.jpg|''The Death of Actaeon'' </gallery>
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== *Jaffé, David (ed), ''Titian'', The National Gallery Company/Yale, London 2003, {{ISBN|1 857099036}} (no. 37, catalogue entry by [[Nicholas Penny]]) *[[Nicholas Penny|Penny, Nicholas]], National Gallery Catalogues (new series): ''The Sixteenth Century Italian Paintings, Volume II, Venice 1540-1600'', pp. 248-259, 2008, National Gallery Publications Ltd, {{ISBN|1857099133}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2NDWLXrq05E ''The Death of Actaeon''] with x-ray views; [http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/paintings/learn-about-art/titians-poesie-paintings "Titian’s ‘poesie’ paintings"], National Gallery videos *[http://sites.google.com/site/beautyandterror/Home/the-terror-of-beauty Essay on this painting from the book ''Beauty and Terror'' by Brian A. Oard]
{{Titian}}

revision.comment: Bot: Removing [[Commons:File:55. The Trinity Session.jpg]] ([[:File:55. The Trinity Session.jpg|en]]). It was deleted on Commons by [[:Commons:User:Jcb|Jcb]] (No OTRS permission for 30 days -).
revision.text:
The '''Trinity Session''' is a [[contemporary art]] production team directed by [[Stephen Hobbs]] and [[Marcus Neustetter]].
The Trinity Session is defined by exchanges with their home-city [[Johannesburg]] ([[South Africa]], in relation to Africa and similar developed / developing contexts. Key activities include temporary interventions and performances, in addition to producing and curating large scale public art programmes. Concerned with context specific technology applications and site-specific social practices, the artistic output of Hobbs/Neustetter, guided by issues of urban decay, xenophobia and public access, results in live actions and video documentation works.
Some of the most recent works of The Trinity Session include: ''Temporary But Permanent Projects'' a Survey exhibition at Museum of African Design, Johannesburg (2015) and ''at The Athenaeum'' in Port Elizabeth (South Africa, 2014); Renaming the City, commissioned artwork for the Ars Electronica Festival in Linz (Austria, 2015); ''Exquisite Corpse'', a video performance presented at the Subtle Tech festival in Toronto (Canada, 2014);'' Platform 1'', a public intervention with the Swallows Foundation, GIFT Festival in Gateshead (United Kingdom, 2013); ''Bessengue B’etoukoa'' a public intervention in Douala commissioned for Across the board: ''Public Space/ Public Sphere'' curated by Elvira Dyangani Ose (Tate Modern, London), for the SUD – Salon Urbain de Douala 2013 (Cameroon); ''ATAYA'', a public performance France/South Africa Cultural Seasons in St Ouen and Paris (France, 2013); ''Fluid Stop'', a site-specific installation and public projection at Greenhouse, St Etienne (France).
==Bibliography== * Andrew Lamprecht, The Trinity Session in Sophie Perryer, 10 years 100 artists: art in a democratic South Africa, Struik, 2004, p. 374 * Penny Siopis, The Space Between in "Art South Africa", vol 1, n. 3, Autumn 2003. * Mary Stuart, Bursting with Ideas for Arc in "The Sunday Independent, 04/07/2004. * Njami, Simon. Africa Remix: Contemporary Art of a Continent. Jacana Media, 2007, p. 247. * Cremona, Vicki Ann, Rikard Hoogland, Gay Morris, and Willmar Sauter. Playing Culture: * Conventions and Extensions of Performance. Rodopi, 2014, p. 101. * The South African Art Information Directory: The SAAID Art Directory. Global Art Information, 2010, p. 15 * Hopkins, D., and K. Solga. Performance and the Global City. Springer, 2013. * Lossau, Julia, and Quentin Stevens. The Uses of Art in Public Space. Routledge, 2014. P. 118 * Pensa, Iolanda (Ed.) 2017. Public Art in Africa. Art et transformations urbaines à Douala /// Art and Urban Transformations in Douala. Genève: Metis Presses. {{ISBN|978-2-94-0563-16-6}}
{{Commons|Category:The Trinity Session}}
=== Related articles === * [[List of public art in Douala]]
[[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Arts in South Africa]]

revision.text:
{{Coord|34.063097|-118.359221|display=title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = File:Urban Light Chris Burden LACMA.JPG | image_size = 300px | title = Urban Light | artist = [[Chris Burden]] | year = 2008 | type = [[Assemblage (art)|Assemblage]] | height_imperial = 320.5 | width_imperial = 686.5 | city = Los Angeles, California, United States | length_imperial = 704.5 | imperial_unit = in | museum = [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]] }}
'''''Urban Light''''' (2008) is a large-scale [[assemblage (art)|assemblage]] [[sculpture]] by [[Chris Burden]] located at the Wilshire Boulevard entrance to the [[Los Angeles County Museum of Art]]. The 2008 installation consists of restored street lamps from the 1920s and 1930s. Most of them once lit the streets of Southern California.<ref name=LATimesYourScene>{{cite news|title=Your Scene: Chris Burden's 'Urban Light' sculpture at LACMA|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/25/entertainment/la-et-urban-light-as-icon-20110125|accessdate=27 February 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=January 25, 2011}}</ref><ref name="LA TimesGlow">{{cite news|last=Freudenheim|first=Susan|title=A glow in the dark: Chris Burden's collection of restored lamps will put LACMA in 'Urban Light.'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jan/30/entertainment/et-burden30|accessdate=27 February 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 30, 2008}}</ref>
== Description == ''Urban Light'' is composed of 202 street lamps arranged in a near grid. The lamps mostly came from the streets of Southern California, including Hollywood, Glendale, and Anaheim, with some from Portland, Oregon. There are 16 different streetlight models represented, many of which were commissioned for particular neighborhoods and streets.<ref>Mandelkern, India (February 20, 2018) [https://unframed.lacma.org/2018/02/20/great-streetlight-scavenger-hunt "The Great Streetlight Scavenger Hunt"] Unframed. Retrieved 5-24-18.</ref> The Broadway Rose, the largest and most ornate of the models, is represented by six lamps. The style was found in [[downtown Los Angeles]]; a few can still be seen on Sixth Avenue between Olive and Flower Streets.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mandelkern|first1=India|title=Urban Light: A Field Guide|date=February 9, 2018|publisher=LACMA|location=Los Angeles|pages=24|edition=1|url=https://www.thelacmastore.org/products/chris-burdens-urban-light-a-field-guide|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref> The sculpture's glass globes are of three general shapes: round, acorn, and cone. The 309 LED bulbs are solar powered and switch on from dusk until dawn, governed by an [[astronomical timer]].<ref name="LACMA-CBurden">{{cite web|url=https://collections.lacma.org/node/214966|title=LACMA collections: Chris Burden|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Los Angeles County Art Museum|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-ca-cm-lacma-urban-light-20180214-htmlstory.html|title='Urban Light': Everything you didn't know about L.A.'s beloved landmark|last=Vankin|first=Deborah|date=February 14, 2018|website=latimes.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>
Writing in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', Susan Freudenheim described the restored lamps as displaying "elaborate floral and geometric patterns" at the base, with "fluted shafts and glass globes that cap them...meticulously cleaned, painted and refurbished to create an exuberant glow."<ref name="LA TimesGlow" />
== History == [[File:Urban_Light_By_Day.jpg|thumb|left|left|''Urban Light'' by daylight as seen from Wilshire Blvd.]] Burden viewed his sculpture as a formal entry way to the museum on [[Wilshire Boulevard]]: "I've been driving by these buildings for 40 years, and it's always bugged me how this institution turned its back on the city."<ref name="LA TimesGlow" />
Burden first began collecting street lamps in December 2000 without a specific work in mind, and continued collecting them for the next seven years. He purchased his first two lamps at the [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Rose Bowl]] Flea Market at $800 each after they were pointed out by curator [[Paul Schimmel (curator)|Paul Schimmel]]'s son Max. The vendor, Jeff Levine, had been restoring the lamps by salvaging parts and later sold Burden more of his collection. Burden purchased others from contractor and collector Anna Justice, who was instrumental in the restoration of sandblasting, recasting missing parts, rewiring to code, and then painting a uniform grey. As Burden's collection grew, the ground around his [[Topanga Canyon]] studio became littered with parts, which the artist referred to as "lamp carcasses".<ref name="LA TimesGlow" /><ref name=LACMA-CBurden /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://unframed.lacma.org/2018/02/06/story-urban-light|title=The Story of Urban Light (including a December 2008 conversation between Michael Govan and Chris Burden)|last=|first=|date=|website=unframed.lacma.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-05}}</ref>
In late 2003, Burden discussed installing a hundred of the lamps at the [[Gagosian Gallery]] in New York, but the gallery eventually balked at the cost. While he later sent 14 lamps to an exhibition in London, his goal was to keep as much of his then 150-piece collection together as possible. To that end, he invited visitors to view the street lamps outside his studio, where he had installed them in dense rows on two sides of the building.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chris Burden: Extreme Measures|last=Philips|first=Lisa|last2=Johanna Burton|publisher=New Museum, New York and Skira Rizzoli Publications|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=208–209|quote=|display-authors=1|via=}}</ref> Among the prospective purchasers in mid-2006 was The [[Museum für angewandte Kunst Wien|MAK Museum for Applied Art]] in Vienna and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, represented by its new director, [[Michael Govan]]. He visited the studio at twilight, and from the driveway, saw the lights lit and concluded that the installation would be a perfect fit. Govan was followed by Andrew M. Gordon, a [[Goldman Sachs]] executive who would later become chairman of the museum's board. Gordon approved the purchase through his family foundation for an undisclosed price.<ref name="LA TimesGlow" />
''Urban Light'' was preceded by [[Sheila Klein]]'s ''[[Vermonica]]'' (1993)'','' which placed 25 Los Angeles street lamps in a parking lot at the corner of Vermont Avenue and Santa Monica Boulevards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/paul-haddad/meet-las-original-urban-l_b_7528372.html|title=Meet L.A.'s Original 'Urban Light'|date=June 8, 2015|publisher=The Huffington Post|issue=|agency=|ref=|last1=Haddad|first1=Paul|accessdate=August 18, 2015}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+Timeline: opening and beyond |- |2008 |''Urban Light'' opens at LACMA.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/museums/la-et-cm-urban-light-lacma-restoration-story.html|title=LACMA's well-known 'Urban Light' will go dark for two months|last=Hill|first=Libby|date=March 24, 2016|publisher=Los Angeles Times|access-date=February 17, 2017}}</ref> |- |2011 |Another large Chris Burden work, the kinetic sculpture ''[[Metropolis II (sculpture)|Metropolis II]]''[[Metropolis II (sculpture)|,]] opens in an adjacent building.<ref>''Chrish Burden: Metropolis II'' (Museum plaque). Los Angeles County Art Museum</ref> |- |2012 |Burden produces a model for ''Xanadu'', another street lamp-themed installation, which would place 58 lights on every exterior ledge of the [[New Museum]] building in New York.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chris Burden: Extreme Measures|last=Philips|first=Lisa|last2=Johanna Burton|publisher=New Museum, New York and Skira Rizzoli Publications|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|page=195|quote=|display-authors=1|via=}}</ref> |- |2015 |Second restoration: over a two-month period, the museum scrubs the lamps down to cast iron and applies a more durable paint deemed to have "the right sheen for the sculpture" and that meets California's [[volatile organic compound]] regulations.<ref name=":0" /> |- |2018 |The museum retrofits the lamps with [[Light-emitting diode|LED]] bulbs that match the intensity and color of the original [[Incandescent light bulb|incandescents]]. The move follows a two-year study and funding from the [[Leonardo DiCaprio|Leonardo DiCaprio Foundation]].<ref name=":1" /> |}
===Critical reception=== The ''Urban Light'' installation took place amid changes to the LACMA campus, which included a new building, the Broad Contemporary Art Museum, and two new open spaces. The sculpture dominates one of them, a [[forecourt]] located between Wilshire Boulevard and LACMA's entry pavilion.<ref name="HawthorneReview" />
''Los Angeles Times'' critic Christopher Hawthorne gave the arrangement a mixed review, describing ''Urban Light'' as "a kind of pop temple, deftly straddling the lines between art and architecture and between seriousness and irony." "It's also a joy to walk through, but there's no getting around the fact that it turns what might have been an actual public square along Wilshire—a space defined from day to day by the people using it—into an outdoor room for one sizable and very insistent piece of art."<ref name="HawthorneReview">{{cite news|last=Hawthorne|first=Christopher|title=ARCHITECTURE REVIEW; County museum's expansion reflects two clashing visions; The new building is Eli Broad's realm, while LACMA's director applies his influence elsewhere|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/feb/07/entertainment/et-bcamarch7|accessdate=29 February 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=February 7, 2008}}</ref> Hawthorne also argued that ''Urban Light'' was the first of four large-scale installations at LACMA in which Michael Govan challenged and undermined "the polite axial symmetry of the master plan he inherited from" architect [[Renzo Piano]] and his patrons. Those installations also include Tony Smith's black aluminum sculpture, called "Smoke", that fills the atrium of the Ahmanson Building, a palm garden by [[Robert Irwin (artist)|Robert Irwin]] installed along the edge of the Resnick Pavilion, and, just north, [[Michael Heizer]]'s ''[[Levitated Mass]]''.<ref name="LA Times Large scale art">{{cite news|last=Hawthorne|first=Christopher|title=Critic's Notebook: Art on an architectural scale at LACMA|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-rock-notebook-20120708,0,1083093.story|accessdate=7 July 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=July 7, 2012}}</ref>
Although ''Urban Light'' fills what had been Renzo Piano's planned "public square" space, it nevertheless succeeded where the empty public space dismally failed. K. M. Williamson, social ecologist and director of [[Public Art in Public Places]], saw ''Urban Light'' as not reducing the plaza space but instead fundamentally redefining it and enlivening it.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apalosangeles.org/public-art-in-public-places-l-a-s-iconic-urban-light/|title=L.A.'s Iconic "Urban Light": August is Art Appreciation Month - What if it was also Public Space Planning Appreciation Month?"|last=Williamson|first=K. M.|date=August 15, 2014|website=American Planning Association {{!}} Los Angeles|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 21, 2018}}</ref> Michael Govan believed that ''Urban Light'' imparted a "feeling of walking through an ancient temple", one that echos the Greco-Roman temple facades of many East Coast museums. Those facades "are really faux; they’re neoclassical,...and here [Burden has] assembled an honest-to-goodness Los Angeles temple made of local materials, in our time."<ref name=":2" /> ,
==Cultural status== Since its 2008 installation, ''Urban Light'' has become an extremely popular attraction. According to Public Art in Public Places, ''Urban Light'' has become the most visited, photographed and well-known public artwork in Southern California.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://artsandculture.google.com/asset/urban-light/vgGacTHf37eEwQ|title=Urban Light - Chris Burden 2008|last=Public Art in Public Places|first=|date=2016|website=Google Arts & Culture|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 21, 2018}}</ref> Director [[Ivan Reitman]] was one of the first filmmakers to incorporate the public artwork in a motion picture, using the location for a scene in his film ''[[No Strings Attached (film)|No Strings Attached]]''. Echoing Burden's own view,<ref name="LA TimesGlow" /> he called the artwork "an extraordinary beacon" that "lights up a desperate part of Wilshire that felt almost abandoned at night." ''Urban Light'' was featured in the [[Tori Amos]] video ''Maybe California'' and the film ''[[Valentine's Day (2010 film)|Valentine's Day]]''. The work appeared in a [[Guinness]] commercial and in a ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' article featuring cast members of the television series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'', as well as in numerous amateur photos posted online. LACMA itself has featured the work as part of its own promotional efforts, including a 3D public service announcement preceding the film ''[[Megamind]]''.<ref name=LATimes-sceens>{{cite news|last=Finkel|first=Jori|title='Urban Light' lights up the screen|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/25/entertainment/la-et-urban-light-as-icon-20110125|accessdate=27 February 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> In 2014, the sculpture was used in a dance scene in VH1's [[Hit the Floor (TV series)|''Hit the Floor'']].<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://twitter.com/Dance9Tiffany/status/473676624366665728|title = Tiffany Maher feed: 'A night I will never forget ~ @hitthefloor #devilgirls @LACMA @VH1'|date = June 2, 2014|website = Twitter|publisher = |last = Maher|first = Tiffany}}</ref>
The first known selfie taken at the sculpture was shot four days after the work opened and was posted to [[Flickr]]. The sculpture has its own hashtag: #urbanlight. While not rented out as a wedding site, ''Urban Light'' has been the setting for many vows.<ref name=":1" />
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}

revision.comment: italicize title, first mention, and first caption, add further italics and an upper case fix
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Vollard Suite.2869.jpg|thumb|Prints from the ''Vollard Suite'']]
The '''''Vollard Suite''''' is a set of 100 [[etching]]s in the [[Neoclassicism|neoclassical style]] by the Spanish artist [[Pablo Picasso]], produced from 1930-37. Named for the art dealer who commissioned them, [[Ambroise Vollard]] (1866-1939), the suite is in a number of museums, and individual etchings from the suite are collectible. More than 300 sets were created, but many were broken up and the prints sold separately.<ref name="TelegNov11">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-news/8923722/City-fund-manager-in-1m-Picasso-giveaway.html|title=City fund manager in £1m Picasso giveaway|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|author=Anita Singh|accessdate=2012-05-19|date=2011-11-29|location=London}}</ref>
==History== In 1930 Picasso was commissioned to produce the etchings by the art dealer and publisher Ambroise Vollard in exchange for paintings by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]] and [[Paul Cézanne]].<ref name="TelegMay12">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-reviews/9251599/Picasso-The-Vollard-Suite-British-Museum-review.html|title=Picasso, The Vollard Suite, British Museum, review|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|author=Richard Dormant|accessdate=2012-05-19|date=2012-05-08|location=London}}</ref>.
Picasso worked extensively on the set in the spring of 1933, and completed the suite in 1937.<ref name="TelegMay12">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/art-reviews/9251599/Picasso-The-Vollard-Suite-British-Museum-review.html|title=Picasso, The Vollard Suite, British Museum, review|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|author=Richard Dormant|accessdate=2012-05-19|date=2012-05-08|location=London}}</ref> It took a further two years for the printmaker Roger Lacourière to finish printing the 230 full sets, but the death of Vollard in 1939 and the Second World War meant that the sets only started coming onto the art market in the 1950s.<ref name="TelegMay12"/>
A 1971 exhibition of the suite in Madrid was attacked by a [[paramilitary]] group, the Guerrilleros del Christo Rey ([[Warriors of Christ the King]]) who tore the pictures and poured acid over the prints. The group attacked things associated with Spanish exiles like Picasso who aligned themselves with the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republican cause]] in the [[Spanish Civil War]]<ref name="Hensbergen2005">{{cite book|author=Gijs Van Hensbergen|title=Guernica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8TO5wF6wUfoC&pg=PA268|accessdate=19 May 2012|date=1 October 2005|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-0-7475-6873-5|pages=268–}}</ref>.
A [[moving skyscraper|spinning residential building]] in Brazil was named [[Suite Vollard]] after the suite.<ref name="EconMar09">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/13174449|title=Monitor:Revolutionary Buildings|publisher=''[[The Economist]]''|author=Jane Kinsman|accessdate=2012-05-19|date=2009-03-07}}</ref>
A complete set is owned by the [[National Gallery of Australia]]<ref name="NatGalAus">{{cite web|url=http://nga.gov.au/exhibitions/picasso/index.html|title=Vollard Suite|publisher=[[National Gallery of Australia]]|author=Jane Kinsman|accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref> and a complete set was acquired by the [[British Museum]] in 2011 after a donation of £1 million from financier Hamish Parker, a director of Mondrian Investment Partners. The donation was in memory of Parker's father, Major Horace Parker<ref name="TelegNov11"/>. It had been the British Museum's ambition to own the set and the acquisition was described by the museum's director, [[Neil MacGregor]], as "one of the institution's most important acquisitions of the past 50 years"<ref name="TelegNov11"/>.
==The series== The works are not based on a literary source, and are not titled, although according to the [[Fundación Juan March]], "Some of the themes have a remote origin in [[Honoré de Balzac]]’s short story ''Le Chef-d’oeuvre inconnu'' (The Unknown Masterpiece, 1831), which greatly impressed Picasso. It tells the story of a painter’s efforts to capture life itself on canvas through the means of feminine beauty".<ref>[http://www.march.es/arte/ingles/cuenca/exposiciones/picasso/picasso.asp Vollard Suite], Museo de Arte Abstracto Español (Fundación Juan March)</ref> The works are inscribed by Picasso with the year month and day that he drew the image.<ref name="TelegMay12"/> Writing in the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' Richard Dorment claims that as Picasso took such a long time to create the suite, "the imagery and the emotional register of the prints constantly shifts to reflect Picasso's erotic and artistic obsessions, marital vicissitudes, and the darkening political situation in Europe...In the years Picasso worked on the series, fascism spread through Europe, and civil war erupted in Spain. These anxieties also found their way into the Vollard Suite, so that by the time you reach the end of the show and the last images of the blind minotaur, you feel that you are in a different emotional universe from the sunlit [[Arcadia (utopia)|arcadia]] you encountered at the show’s beginning".<ref name="TelegMay12"/>
The suite begins with prints exploring the theme of the sculptor's studio, Picasso's mistress, [[Marie-Thérèse Walter]], is portrayed as a model lying in the arms of a bearded sculptor. Picasso had recently been inspired by Marie-Thérèse to create a series of monumental bronze heads in the neoclassical style.<ref name="TelegMay12"/> Picasso had also recently been commissioned by the publisher [[Albert Skira]] in 1928 to create original [[intaglio (printmaking)|intaglio]] prints for his translation of [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]'', which appeared in 1931.<ref name="NatGalAus"/>
Dorment comments that a [[minotaur]] appears, joining in scenes of bacchic excess, but the minotaur is transformed from a gentle lover and bon vivant into a rapist and devourer of women, reflecting Picasso's turbulent relationships with Marie-Thérèse and his wife Olga.<ref name="TelegMay12"/> In a third transformation, the minotaur becomes pathetic, blind and impotent, he wanders by night, led by a little girl with the features of Marie-Thérèse.<ref name="TelegMay12"/> The final three prints from the suite are portraits of Vollard.<ref name="Tate">{{cite web|url=http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/picasso-faun-revealing-a-sleeping-woman-jupiter-and-antiope-after-rembrandt-p11360|title=Vollard Suite|publisher=[[Tate]]|accessdate=2012-05-19}}</ref>
Picasso learned new techniques of etching during the suite, from relatively simple line etchings, through [[Burin (engraving)|burin]], [[dry point]], [[aquatinting]] and sugar aquatinting learnt through {{ill|Roger Lacourière|fr}} in his workshop<ref>{{Cite web|language=fr|url=http://www.mchampetier.com/sitephp/phpfr/det_cimaise.php?page_numero=3&nom_cim=Atelier%20Lacouri%E8re%20&%20Fr%E9laut|title=Atelier Lacourière & Frélaut|website=mchampetier.com|year=2014|access-date=2014-06-08|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140608111033/http://www.mchampetier.com/sitephp/phpfr/det_cimaise.php?page_numero=3&nom_cim=Atelier%20Lacouri%E8re%20&%20Fr%E9laut|archive-date=2014-06-08|dead-url=yes|df=}}.</ref>, this enabled him to achieve more painterly effects.<ref name="TelegMay12"/> Most of the prints were completed to Picasso's satisfaction in a single [[state (printmaking)|state]], but others, especially the erotic compositions, exist in several states, fourteen in one case.
==Collections with complete sets== {{expand list|date=September 2017}} * [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]], département des Estampes * [[British Museum]] * [[Colby College Museum of Art]]<ref>[http://www.colby.edu/news/2016/05/06/picasso-suite/], accessed May 9, 2016</ref> * [[Fundación MAPFRE]], Madrid<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.ph/previousexhibitions.php Metropolitan Museum of Manila], accessed May 19, 2012</ref> * [[Harry Ransom Center]] * [[Hood Museum of Art]], [[Hanover, New Hampshire]]<ref>[http://hoodmuseum.dartmouth.edu/collections/overview/europe/paper/prints/ Prints], Hood Museum of Art, [[Dartmouth College]], accessed May 19, 2012</ref> * {{ill|Kunstmuseum Pablo Picasso Münster|de}}<ref>[http://www.kunstmuseum-picasso-muenster.de/en/museum/collections/pablo-picasso-the-suite-vollard/]</ref> * [[Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth]]<ref>[http://themodern.org/exhibition/past/Picasso-The-Vollard-Suite/640 Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth] web page</ref> * [[Museum Ludwig]], [[Cologne]]<ref>[http://www.museenkoeln.de/museum-ludwig/default.asp?s=1844 The Graphic Collection at Museum Ludwig], accessed May 19, 2012</ref> * {{ill|Museo de Arte Contemporáneo de Caracas|es}} (MACC)<ref>http://www.ciudadccs.info/?p=247389</ref> * [[National Gallery of Australia]] * [[National Gallery of Canada]] * [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] <ref>[http://www.philamuseum.org/exhibitions/1991/550.html]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *Bolliger, Hans (1977). ''Picasso's Vollard Suite''. New York: Harry N. Abrams. {{ISBN|9780810920767}}. *Coppel, Stephen (2012). ''Picasso Prints: The Vollard Suite''. British Museum Press. {{ISBN|9780714126838}}.
==External links== *[http://nga.gov.au/exhibitions/picasso/index.html The ''Vollard Suite'' at the National Gallery of Australia] *[https://ledorfineart.com/guide-collecting-picassos-original-prints/chapter-6-a-survey-of-picassos-prints-1930-1944-the-vollard-suite-through-dora-maar/ A guide to collecting Picasso's prints - The ''Vollard Suite''] *[http://www.moma.org/search/collection?query=Vollard+Suite The ''Vollard Suite'' at MoMA (35)]
{{Pablo Picasso}}

{{infobox military memorial |name=War Memorial Cross, Beeston |country=[[United Kingdom]] |body= |image=[[File:Beeston World War Memorial - geograph.org.uk - 724881.jpg|250px]] |caption= |commemorates=Men of Beeston who died in the first and second world wars. |use_dates= |coordinates= {{coord|52.924312|-1.215625|display=inline,title}} |location=[[Beeston, Nottinghamshire]] |nearest_town= |designer=[[William Herbert Higginbottom]] |inscription= |established= <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |unveiled= |total= |unknowns= |commemorated= |by_country= |by_war= |source= }}
'''War Memorial Cross, Beeston''' is a [[Grade II listed]]<ref>{{IoE|429361|accessdate=20 April 2015}}</ref> structure in [[Beeston, Nottinghamshire]].
==History==
It was designed by the architect [[William Herbert Higginbottom]]. Constructed in Portland stone it comprises an octagonal plinth of 3 steps, the top step ornamented. The square plinth contains recessed panels, 3 of them are inscribed. The plinth is topped with a Celtic cross with panelled tapered square shaft.
The memorial was constructed in the early 1920s to commemorate the dead of the [[First World War]]. Additional inscriptions were added in 1945.
The inscriptions read: *By their Valour and the grace of God, they Won. *In grateful memory of those who gave their lives in the Great War 1914 – 1918 *World War 1939 – 1945
It was restored in 2009.<ref>http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/40-000-scheme-improve-Beeston-war-memorial/story-12262805-detail/story.html#axzz2RqUQnVlH</ref>

{{other uses}} [[File:Yellow Arrow sticker in New York City.jpg|thumb|A Yellow Arrow sticker in New York CIty]] '''''Yellow Arrow''''' was a public art project created by Christopher Allen, [[Brian House]], and [[Jesse Shapins]] that was active from 2004-2006. The project is an important example of [[locative media]] and mobile phone art and draws concepts from [[psychogeography]].
''Yellow Arrow'' stickers were obtained from the project website<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/01/AR2005070102280.html |title=Targeting the 'Art' Around Every Corner |publisher=washingtonpost.com |date= 2005-07-02|accessdate=2011-04-10 |first=Tommy |last=Nguyen}}</ref> and placed anywhere in the public realm. When encountering a sticker on the street, one could send the unique code printed on it as a [[short message service|text message]] to the project phone number. Moments later a message would be received that was left by the person who placed the sticker.
The ''Yellow Arrow'' symbol means "there’s more here: a hidden detail, a funny story, a memory, and a crazy experience." Each arrow linked digital content to a specific location using the mobile phone.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/25/technology/techspecial2/25geo.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=%22yellow%20arrow%22&st=cse | work=The New York Times | first=Ethan | last=Todras-Whitehill | title=Making Connections, Here and Now | date=2006-01-25}}</ref>
As an underground phenomenon, the project developed an international community, and 7535 ''Yellow Arrow'' stickers were placed in 467 cities and 35 countries.<ref>{{cite web|last=House|first=Brian|title=Yellow Arrow|url=http://brianhouse.net/works/yellow_arrow/|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref> Since first appearing at the [[Psy-Geo-Conflux]] in New York in May 2004, ''Yellow Arrow'' has been featured in The New York Times, Wired,<ref>{{cite news|last=Howe|first=Jeff|title=Text in the City|url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/12.09/play.html?pg=3|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=Wired|date=September 2004}}</ref> Newsweek, The Washington Post,<ref>{{cite news|last=Nguyen|first=Tommy|title=Targeting the 'Art' Around Every Corner|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/07/01/AR2005070102280.html|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=2005-07-02}}</ref> The Boston Globe, CNN and NBC, the London Times, Politiken,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://politiken.dk/kultur/fakta_kultur/ECE115054/yellow-arrow---et-globalt-kunstprojekt/|title=Yellow Arrow - et globalt kunstprojekt |trans-title=Yellow Arrow - a global art project|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=Politiken|date=2005-06-06}}</ref> Liberation, [[Diari de Barcelona]], and de Volkskrant. ''Yellow Arrow'' was also featured in Lonely Planet's Guide to Experimental Travel.
In ''Toward the Sentient City'', Mark Shepard writes, "In place of the ubiquitous bronze plaque providing "official narratives" affixed to the side of "significant" urban structures or spaces, ''Yellow Arrow'' provides for the unofficial annotation of everyday urban places by ordinary citizens."<ref>{{cite book|last=Shepard|first=Mark|title=Sentient City|year=2011|publisher=MIT Press|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|isbn=978-0-262-51586-3|pages=28}}</ref>
''Yellow Arrow'' was included in the exhibition ''Design and the Elastic Mind'' at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York City in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=MoMA.org {{!}} Design and The Elastic Mind|url=http://www.moma.org/interactives/exhibitions/2008/elasticmind/|accessdate=14 September 2012}}</ref>
In 2006, the project was discontinued and its content was archived on [[Flickr]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://brianhouse.net/works/yellow_arrow/ Yellow Arrow website] *[https://www.flickr.com/photos/yellowarrow/collections/ Yellow Arrow archive on flickr]
